Fig. 1 Catalytic performance evaluation for catalysts. (A) Variation in conversion of Maleic Anhydride (MA) with reaction time. (B) Variation in selectivity of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) with reaction time. (C) Variation in selectivity of γ-butyrolactone (GBL) with reaction time. (D) Variation in yield of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) with reaction time. (E) Variation in yield of γ-butyrolactone (GBL) with reaction time. (F) The yield changes with the increase of Cu content. Reaction conditions: 210 °C, 3 MPa hydrogen pressure, 500 rpm, 2.45 g maleic anhydride, 0.05 g catalyst, 40 mL 1,4-dioxane, reaction time: 8 h. Fig. 2 (A) Comparison of the performance of Ni/Al2O3 catalysts with different reaction temperature. Reaction conditions: 3 MPa hydrogen pressure, 500 rpm, 2.45 g maleic anhydride, 0.05 g catalyst, 40 mL 1,4-dioxane, reaction time: 8 h. (B) Comparison of the performance of Ni/Al2O3 catalysts with different reaction pressure. Reaction conditions: 210 °C, 500 rpm, 2.45 g maleic anhydride, 0.05 g catalyst, 40 mL 1,4-dioxane, reaction time: 8 h. (C) Comparison of the performance of NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalysts with different reaction temperatures. Reaction conditions: 3 MPa hydrogen pressure, 500 rpm, 2.45 g maleic anhydride, 0.05 g catalyst, 40 mL 1,4-dioxane, reaction time: 8 h. (D) Comparison of the performance of NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalysts with different reaction pressure. Reaction conditions: 210 °C, 500 rpm, 2.45 g maleic anhydride, 0.05 g catalyst, 40 mL 1,4-dioxane, reaction time: 8 h. (E) Stability test of Ni/Al2O3 catalyst under reaction conditions: 210 °C, 3 MPa hydrogen pressure, 500 rpm, 2.45 g maleic anhydride, 0.05 g catalyst, 40 mL 1,4-dioxane, reaction time: 8 h. (F) Stability test of NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst under reaction conditions: 210 °C, 3 MPa hydrogen pressure, 500 rpm, 2.45 g maleic anhydride, 0.05 g catalyst, 40 mL 1,4-dioxane, reaction time: 8 h. (G) Catalytic performance of Ni/Al2O3 catalyst at different reaction temperature. Reaction conditions: 3 MPa hydrogen pressure, 500 rpm, 2.45 g maleic anhydride as substrates, 0.05 g catalyst, 40 mL 1,4-dioxane. (H) catalytic performance of NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst at different reaction temperature. Reaction conditions: 3 MPa hydrogen pressure, 500 rpm, 2.45 g maleic anhydride as substrate, 0.05 g catalyst, 40 mL 1,4-dioxane. (I) Arrhenius plots for conversion of maleic anhydride over NiCu0.4/Al2O3 and Ni/Al2O3 catalysts. Fig. 3 (A) XRD patterns of LDHs precursor (i) NiAl-LDH (ii) NiCu0.16Al-LDH (iii) NiCu0.25Al-LDH (iv) NiCu0.4Al-LDH (v) NiCu0.57Al-LDH (vi) CuAl-LDH and (B) metal oxide of (i) NiAl-LDO (ii) NiCu0.16Al-LDO (iii) NiCu0.25Al-LDO (iv) NiCu0.4Al-LDO (v) NiCu0.57Al-LDO (vi) CuAl-LDO. (C) XRD patterns of NiCux/Al2O3 catalysts (i) Ni/Al2O3 (ii) NiCu0.16/Al2O3 (iii) NiCu0.25/Al2O3 (iv) NiCu0.4/Al2O3 (v) NiCu0.57/Al2O3 (vi) Cu/Al2O3. (D) H2-TPR profiles of metal oxide of (i) NiAl-LDO (ii) NiCu0.16Al-LDO (iii) NiCu0.25Al-LDO (iv) NiCu0.4Al-LDO (v) NiCu0.57Al-LDO (vi) CuAl-LDO. Fig. 4 (A-B) HRTEM image and average particle size distribution histogram of Ni/Al2O3 catalyst (C) HAADF-STEM image of Ni/Al2O3 catalyst and the corresponding EDX elemental mappings of (c1)Ni, (c2)Al, and (c3)O. Graphical abstract The primary products of the direct hydrogenation of Maleic Anhydride (MA) are Succinic Anhydride (SAH) and γ-butyrolactone (GBL). Achieving selective synthesis of these products by regulating the composition, structure, and textural properties remains a focal point in the research field of maleic anhydride hydrogenation. Based on the characteristic of atomic level uniform distribution of cations of layered double hydroxides (LDHs), a highly loaded, highly dispersed and homogenized NiCu alloy bimetallic catalyst was synthesized using NiCuAl-LDHs as precursor. Compared with Ni/Al2O3 catalyst derived from NiAl-LDHs, the introduction of Cu can effectively improve the hydrogenation activity of C=C bonds while inhibiting the hydrogenolysis of C=O bonds. Under identical reaction conditions, the primary product of the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was γ-butyrolactone (GBL) with a yield of 94.2 %, whereas the primary product of the NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst was Succinic Anhydride (SAH) with a yield of 90.5 %. The introduction of Cu resulted in the formation of a homogeneous NiCu alloy phase in the catalyst, which significantly influenced the adsorption configurations and adsorption energies of the reactants and intermediates. This effect can be attributed to the electronic interactions between Ni and Cu, which shift the d-band center of Ni away from the Fermi energy level, thereby facilitating the directed synthesis of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) and γ-butyrolactone (GBL). These findings were confirmed by various characterization techniques and DFT theoretical calculations. Future catalyst development in maleic anhydride hydrogenation will significantly benefit from the design approach and research ideas presented in this study. Keywords Bimetallic NiCu catalyst D-band center Hydrogenation of maleic anhydride Selectivity Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As an important chemical raw material, a series of highly value-added fine chemicals can be synthesized by the hydrogenation of Maleic Anhydride (MA), such as Succinic Anhydride (SAH), γ-butyrolactone (GBL), Tetrahydrofuran (THF) and 1, 4-butanediol (BDO)[1–3]. According to the literature, the products of direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride are mainly Succinic Anhydride (SAH) and γ-butyrolactone (GBL)[3,4]. Succinic Anhydride (SAH) is an important intermediate of chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and foodstuffs. More importantly, Succinic Anhydride (SAH) is an important raw material for fully biodegradable plastics. With the promulgation and implementation of the global plsatic ban/restriction policies, the demand for succinic anhydride on a global scale will show a rapid growth trend worldwide[5–7]. γ-Butyrolactone (GBL) has a wide and important applications in the fields of pharmaceuticals, pesticides, cosmetics, dyes, and lithium-ion batteries. With the rapid development of global electric vehicle industry, the demand for γ-Butyrolactone (GBL) has also increased rapidly[1,8]. How to achieve the selective and targeted synthesis of hydrogenation products by modulating catalyst composition and structure, and elucidating the catalytic mechanism, is one of the significant challenges in this research field. Due to the synergistic effect between the two metal components, bimetallic catalysts exhibit significantly better catalytic performance than single metal catalysts in many hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis reactions[9–11]. For example, Huiling Zhang et al. investigated the catalytic performance of NiCo bimetallic catalyst for the hydrogenation of furfural to tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol and found that the NiCo bimetallic catalyst achieved a selectivity of 97.6 % for tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol, which was significantly higher than that of the monometallic Ni (75 %) and Co (0 %) catalysts[12]. Wei Luo et al. synthesized molecular sieve-encapsulated PtCu@S-1 bimetallic catalysts for the production of furfuryl alcohol via the hydrogenation of furfural under mild conditions. They observed that the apparent turnover frequency (TOF) values of the bimetallic catalysts were 16 and 4 times higher than those of the monometallic Pt@S-1 and Cu@S-1 catalysts, respectively[13]. Huan Xiang et al. synthesized a silica hollow sphere-supported NixCuy/SiO2 catalyst and evaluated its catalytic performance in the hydrogenation of levulinic acid to produce γ-valerolactone. The results indicated that the NixCuy/SiO2 bimetallic catalyst achieved a 73 % conversion of levulinic acid with 99 % selectivity for γ-valerolactone, demonstrating significantly enhanced catalytic activity compared to the monometallic catalyst[14]. Currently, some bimetallic catalysts utilized for maleic anhydride hydrogenation are based on noble metals, such as Pd-Sn[15,16] and Ru-Re[17,18]. Research on non-noble bimetallic catalysts for this reaction has not been reported. Based on the characteristic of atomic level uniform distribution of cations and lattice confinement advantages of layered double hydroxides (LDHs).[12,19–21]. a highly loaded, highly dispersed and NiCu alloy homogenized NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst was synthesized by using NiCuAl LDHs as precursor in this study. Using the liquid-phase hydrogenation of maleic anhydride as a probe reaction, the structure–activity relationship of the NiCu bimetallic catalysts in the hydrogenation of maleic anhydride was investigated through both experimental and theoretical studies. The results indicate that the introduction of Cu leads to the formation of a homogeneous NiCu alloy phase in the catalyst. Due to the strong electronic interaction between Ni and Cu, the d-band center of Ni shifts away from the Fermi energy level, thereby modulating the adsorption configuration and adsorption energy of the reactants and intermediates on the catalyst surface, which in turn adjust the product distribution. This study provides a solid foundation for design of more efficient selective hydrogenation catalysts for maleic anhydride in future. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (99 %), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (99 %) and Al(NO3)3·9H2O (99 %) were purchased from Kaitong Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Tianjin, China). Urea (99 %) was purchased from Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All chemicals were bought from commercial sources and used without further processing. 2.2 Synthesis of NiCuxAl-LDHs precursors In this study, a series of NiCuxAl-LDHs precursors were synthesized by hydrothermal method using urea as the precipitant. The detailed procedure is as follows: 40 mL of deionized water was used as the solvent, and specific amounts of urea, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, and Al(NO3)3·9H2O were simultaneously dissolved, ensuring that n(Cu2++Ni2+)/n(Al3+) = 2. The mixture was then stirred at room temperature for 1 h and subsequently transferred to a 100 mL hydrothermal reactor, which was placed in an oven at 140 °C for 6 h. After the hydrothermal reaction, the precipitate was washed with deionized water until the pH of the supernatant reached neutrality. The precipitate was then dried in an oven at 100 °C for 6 h to obtain the LDHs precursor, designated as NiCuxAl-LDH, where x = n(Cu2+)/(n(Cu2+) + n(Ni2+))(x = 0, 0.16, 0.25, 0.4, 0.57). Furthermore, we also synthesized CuAl-LDH samples without Ni for comparative analysis, ensuring that n(Cu2+)/n(Al3+) = 2. 2.3 Synthesis of NiCux/Al2O3 catalysts The NiCuxAl-LDH and CuAl-LDH precursor synthesized in section 2.2 was placed in a muffle furnace at 400 °C for 3 h. The resulting samples were designated as NiCuxAl-LDO (LDO: Layered double oxide) and CuAl-LDO. Subsequently, the NiCuxAl-LDO and CuAl-LDO sample was introduced into a tube furnace and heated to the specified temperature under a mixed atmosphere of N2 (30 mL/min) and H2 (60 mL/min) for 3 h. The final catalyst product was labeled as NiCux/Al2O3 and Cu/Al2O3, where x = n(Cu2+)/(n(Cu2+) + n(Ni2+)) (x = 0, 0.16, 0.25, 0.4, 0.57). 2.4 Characterization of materials The crystal structure of all samples was tested on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE instrument produced by the Bruker Company in Germany with an emission wavelength of λ = 1.542 Å, scanning speed of 0.1 s−1, and radiation source of Cu Kα chosen for the scanning range of 5∼80°. Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy tests were performed on a Bruker Vertex 70v spectrometer to characterize the functional groups and molecular bonding information of the material. The calcined and reduced samples were characterised by temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and temperature programmed desorption of hydrogen (H2-TPD), respectively, using Mike Auto Chem-2920 chemisorbent instrument. N2-physical absorption was tested on a Micromeritics ASAP2020 instrument to determine the specific surface area and pore structure information of the catalysts. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were used to characterize the morphology and surface structure of the catalysts, respectively. SEM was performed on a TESCAN MIRA LMS. TEM was performed using a Gatan US1000 894 instrument (FEI Tecnai 20). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) tests were performed on Thermo Scientific K-Alpha instrument with a vacuum of approximately 5*10-9 mbar in the analysing chamber. X-ray source: Monochromated AlKa source (Mono AlKa) Energy: 1486.6 eV, Voltage: 12 KV, Beam current: 6 mA, Analyser Scanning Mode: CAE, Instrument Function: 4.2 eV. All binding energies were calibrated with a C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. 2.5 Catalytic performance evaluation (1) The catalyst performance tests were conducted in an autoclave reactor. Typical reaction conditions included 2.45 g of maleic anhydride, 0.05 g of catalyst, and 40 mL of 1,4-dioxane as the reaction solvent. After sealing the reactor, N2 was introduced to purge the residual air from the vessel. This was followed by pumping in 3 MPa H2 to displace the remaining N2, repeating this process five times. Finally, 3 MPa H2 was introduced again to maintain a constant pressure, and the reactor was heated to the specified temperature. The liquid product was analyzed using gas chromatography (SHIMADZU 2010 GC) equipped with a FID detector and an HP-5 column. The conversion, selectivity and yield were calculated according to the following equations: c o n v e r s i o n % = moles of reactant converted moles of initial reactant × 100 % S e l e c t i v i t y % = moles of product moles of MA converted × 100 % Y i e l d % = C o n v e r s i o n × s e l e c t i v i t y (2) Stability test: The catalysts at the end of the reaction were separated by centrifugation, washed with solvent, and directly reintroduced into the reactor for the next evaluation experiment without any additional operations. 2.6 DFT calculations details In this study, the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) is used for theoretical simulations. The interaction between electrons and ions is described using the Projector Augmented Wave (PAW) method, with a cut-off energy of 400 eV. The convergence criteria for the forces and energies in the geometry optimization process are set to 0.02 eV/Å and 10-5 eV, respectively. The Ni(1 1 1) surfaces are represented by 5 × 5 unit cells with four layers, constraining the bottom two layers and adding a vacuum layer of 15 Å thickness along the c-axis to avoid effects caused by periodic interactions. Relaxation and total energy calculations of the surface structure were performed using a 3 × 3 × 1 k-point mesh, allowing for complete relaxation of at least the top two Ni atomic layers and the adsorbed material. The NiCu(1 1 1) surface is modelled by replacing 50 % of the Ni atoms in the top site of the Ni(1 1 1) cell by Cu atoms. Spin-polarized calculations were used to describe the magnetic properties of the Ni element. The adsorption energy was calculated according to the following equation: E ads = E slab + x - E slab - E x where Eslab+x is the system energy after adsorption, Eslab is the energy of the clean surface, and Ex is the energy of the gas phase adsorbate. The reaction energy barrier (Ea ) and the reaction energy (Er ) were calculated according to the following equation: E a = E TS - E IS E r = E FS - E IS where EIS , EFS and ETS are the energies of the reaction initial state (IS), reaction final state (FS) and Transition State (TS), respectively. 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of catalysts A series of NiCux/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared using NiCuxAl-LDHs as the precursor, and their liquid-phase hydrogenation performance for maleic anhydride was investigated. The evaluation results of the catalytic performance of each catalyst are shown in Fig. 1 . The variation of maleic anhydride conversion on each catalyst with time is shown in Fig. 1 (A). The conversion of maleic anhydride gradually increases with the extension of the reaction time, and the complete conversion can be achieved in all catalysts at 3 h, but there is a significant difference in all catalysts. When the Cu content was gradually increased to 10.5 % (as determined by ICP-OES), the NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst showed the highest activity by achieving 100 % conversion of maleic anhydride in 2 h, while the Ni/Al2O3 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts reached 100 % conversion in 4 h, respectively. Fig. 1 (B), (C) shows the trend of selectivity of the products of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) and γ-butyrolactone (GBL) with time, respectively. As can be seen from the Fig. 1 (B), (C), the selectivity of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) on each catalyst gradually decreases with reaction time, while the selectivity of γ-butyrolactone (GBL) gradually increases. However, the product selectivity changed significantly with the introduction of Cu. The main product of Ni/Al2O3 catalyst is γ-butyrolactone (GBL) with a selectivity of 94.2 % at reaction time of 8 h. The selectivities of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) and Tetrahydrofuran (THF) are 2.97 % and 2.83 %, respectively. The variation of yield of Tetrahydrofuran (THF) with time is shown in Fig. S1 . No THF generation on all catalysts except Ni/Al2O3 catalysts. With the introduction of Cu, the selectivity of γ-butyrolactone (GBL) gradually decreased while that of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) gradually increase. When the Cu content was gradually increased to 10.5 %, the main product of the NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst was Succinic Anhydride (SAH), with a selectivity of 90.5 %, and the selectivity of γ-butyrolactone (GBL) was 9.5 % at reaction time of 8 h. Fig. 1 (D), (E) shows the trends of the yield of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) and γ-butyrolactone (GBL) with the reaction time, respectively. The results showed that the yield of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) on each catalyst gradually increased at the early stage of the reaction time within 1 h and then decreased with the extension of the reaction time. The yield of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) on Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was 2.97 % at 8 h. With the introduction of Cu, the decreasing trend of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) yield on NiCux/Al2O3 catalyst gradually slowed down, among which, NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst had the highest Succinic Anhydride (SAH) yield of 90.5 % at 8 h. In contrast, the yield of γ-butyrolactone (GBL) showed a gradual increase with the extension of the reaction time, and the yield of γ-butyrolactone (GBL) on Ni/Al2O3 catalyst reached 94.2 % when the reaction time to 8 h. With the introduction of Cu, the yield of γ-butyrolactone (GBL) yield gradually decreased, in which the NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst had the lowest γ-butyrolactone (GBL) yield of 9.5 % at the reaction time of 8 h. As illustrated in Scheme 1 , during the hydrogenation of Maleic Anhydride (MA), Maleic Anhydride (MA) is initially hydrogenated at the CC bond to form Succinic Anhydride (SAH), which is an intermediate product of maleic anhydride hydrogenation, followed by C=O hydrogenolysis to produce γ-butyrolactone (GBL) and Tetrahydrofuran (THF)[6,22,23].The evaluation results of the aforementioned catalysts clearly demonstrate that by modulating the composition of the active metals, maleic anhydride can be selectively synthesized into either γ-butyrolactone (GBL) or Succinic Anhydride (SAH) with high selectivity. The Ni/Al2O3 catalyst exhibits high CC hydrogenation and CO hydrogenolysis activity, enabling the highly selective synthesis of γ-butyrolactone (GBL) from maleic anhydride. In contrast, the bimetallic NiCux/Al2O3 catalyst shows high selectivity for CC bond hydrogenation and effectively suppresses the CO hydrogenolysis reaction, thereby facilitating the highly selective formation of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) from maleic anhydride. To further compare the catalytic performances of the two catalysts, the effects of reaction temperature and hydrogen pressure on the catalytic activities of Ni/Al2O3 and NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalysts were investigated separately. Fig. 2 (A) illustrates the impact of reaction temperature on the conversion of maleic anhydride and the selectivity of products for the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. Within the examined temperature range (160∼210 °C), the conversion of maleic anhydride consistently reached 100 %. At a reaction temperature of 160 °C, the selectivity of γ-butyrolactone (GBL) was 54.5 %, and the selectivity of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) was 45.5 %. As the reaction temperature increased to 210 °C, the selectivity of γ-butyrolactone (GBL) rose to 94.2 %, while the selectivity of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) decreased to 2.97 %. The trends of conversion and selectivity with reaction time are shown in Fig. S3 (A–C). These results indicate that increasing the reaction temperature promotes the hydrogenolysis of the CO bond in Succinic Anhydride (SAH) to form γ-butyrolactone (GBL), which is consistent with the findings reported in the literature. Fig. 2 (B) shows the conversion of maleic anhydride and the selectivity of products for the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst at various reaction hydrogen pressure (1∼5 MPa), the trends of conversion and selectivity with reaction time are shown in Fig. S4 (A–C). As can be seen from Fig. 2 (B), the maleic anhydride conversion was 100 % in all the pressure ranges examined. When the reaction pressure was 1 MPa, GBL was the main product of MA hydrogenation, and its selectivity reached 89.5 %, and the selectivity of GBL was increased by further increasing the pressure, and the selectivity reached 94.2 % when the pressure was 3 MPa, and the selectivity was kept constant by further increasing the hydrogen pressure, which indicated that when the hydrogen pressure was greater than 3 MPa, the dissolved amount of hydrogen had been able to satisfy the reaction requirements. Fig. 2 (C) illustrates the conversion of maleic anhydride and the selectivity of products for the NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst at various reaction temperatures. Within the examined temperature range and under identical reaction conditions, the conversion of maleic anhydride consistently reaches 100 %. At a reaction temperature of 160 °C, only Succinic Anhydride (SAH) is detected in the products. As the reaction temperature increases, only a minor amount of γ-butyrolactone (GBL) is produced. Even when the reaction temperature is raised to 210 °C, the selectivity of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) remains as high as 90.5 %, while the selectivity of γ-butyrolactone (GBL) is only 9.5 %. The trends of conversion and selectivity with reaction time are shown in Fig. S3 (D–F). Fig. 2 (D) shows the conversion of maleic anhydride and the selectivity of products for the NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst at various reaction hydrogen pressure (1∼5 MPa), the trends of conversion and selectivity with reaction time are shown in Fig. S4 (D–F). As can be seen from Fig. 2 (D), the maleic anhydride conversion was 100 % in all the pressure ranges examined. When the reaction pressure was 1 MPa, SAH was the main product of MA hydrogenation, and its selectivity reached 95.3 %, and the selectivity of SAH was decreased by further increasing the pressure, and the selectivity reached 90.5 % when the pressure was 3 MPa, and the selectivity was kept constant by further increasing the hydrogen pressure, this phenomenon also indicated that when the hydrogen pressure was greater than 3 MPa, the dissolved amount of hydrogen had been able to satisfy the reaction requirements. The effect of temperature and pressure on the catalytic performance was further investigated to show that the Ni/Al2O3 catalysts exhibited high CC hydrogenation and CO hydrogenolysis activities, enabling the highly selective synthesis of γ-butyrolactone (GBL). In contrast, the NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst was highly selective for CC bond hydrogenation and effectively inhibited the CO hydrogenolysis reaction, thus facilitating the highly selective production of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) from Maleic Anhydride (MA). The stability of the Ni/Al2O3 and NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalysts was evaluated through cyclic test experiments, and the results are presented in Fig. 2 (E) and Fig. 2 (F), respectively. After five cycles of testing, no significant decrease in catalyst activity was observed. Under the tested conditions, the selectivity of the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst for γ-butyrolactone (GBL) remained consistently around 95 %, while the selectivity of the NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst for Succinic Anhydride (SAH) was stably around 90 %. Additionally, no other by-products were detected. The Ni/Al2O3 and NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalysts exhibited excellent catalytic performance compared to the reported catalysts in the literature, even better than some noble metal catalysts, as shown in Table S1 . Subsequently, the effects of Ni/Al2O3 and NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalysts on the C=C bond hydrogenation activity of Maleic Anhydride (MA) were further compared by kinetic studies as described in the supporting information Fig. S5 and Fig. S6 . Firstly, as shown in Fig. S5 , the effect of internal and external diffusion on the reaction mass transfer was eliminated by adjusting the stirring speed and catalyst particle size. Subsequently, the trends of MA conversion with reaction time were recorded at lower reaction temperatures (70, 80, and 90 °C), and the results are shown in Fig. 2 (G) and (H), respectively. The figures show that the conversion of maleic anhydride increases significantly with the increase of reaction temperature. The conversion data were taken from the reaction time of 20 min at different reaction temperatures and plotted as −ln(1-X) versus reaction time. The fitted curve shown in Fig. S6 was obtained by linear fitting, and it was found that −ln(1-X) showed a linear relationship with the reaction time, which indicated that the hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to succinic anhydride was a first-order reaction, and the slopes of the linear equations in the graphs indicated that the reaction rate constants k at different temperature, and then according to the Arrhenius equation, the apparent activation energies of Ni/Al2O3 catalyst and NiCu0.4/Al2O3 for the hydrogenation of CC bond were calculated to be 27.3 and 17.6 kJ/mol, respectively. It is worth noting that the hydrogenation activity of the C=C bond on the NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst is significantly higher than that on the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. 3.2 Synthesis and structural analysis of catalysts First, the LDHs precursor was synthesized using the urea hydrothermal method, and the catalyst was subsequently prepared through calcination and reduction, as shown in Scheme S1 . The XRD pattern of the LDHs are shown in Fig. 3 (A). Characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to the (003), (006), (012), (015), (018), (110), and (113) planes of LDHs were observed at 2θ values of 11.5°, 22.7°, 34.7°, 39.1°, 46.3°, 60.8°, and 62.2°, respectively[22,23]. The peaks are well-defined and no impurity peaks are present, indicating the successful synthesis of LDHs with high crystallinity. To gain more insights into the structure of LDHs, the functional groups and bonding information of the samples were characterized using FT-IR. The results are presented in Fig. S7 . The characteristic infrared vibration peak at approximately 3400 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibrations of the OH functional groups on the surface of the LDHs metal layers and the OH functional groups of the interlayer water molecules. The characteristic peak at approximately 1620 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibrations of the OH functional groups of the interlayer water molecules. The characteristic peak at approximately 1350 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibrations of the interlayer CO3 2– groups. The characteristic peaks below approximately 800 cm−1 were attributed to the stretching vibrations of the MO, MOM, and OMO modes (M being Ni, Cu, or Al)[22,24]. These results further confirm the successful synthesis of well-structured LDHs precursors through the urea hydrothermal method. We propose the specific formation process of layered double hydroxides (LDHs) as follows: under hydrothermal conditions, urea undergoes gradual hydrolysis to generate CO3 2– and OH–, leading to an increase in the pH value of the reaction solution. Metal ions progressively react with CO3 2– and OH– to form precipitates. During the precipitation process, the initially formed primary particles collide with each other to form larger aggregates. These larger aggregates attract metastable smaller particles, and through the processes of dissolution and recrystallization, nanoplatelets are gradually formed. Due to the high surface energy of the nanoplatelets, they self-assemble and stack through electrostatic interactions under the influence of hydrothermal conditions, forming stable three-dimensional porous flower-like structures[12,25,26]. This process results in the formation of LDHs with high crystallinity and uniformity. The XRD patterns of the calcined samples are presented in Fig. 3 (B). Characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) planes of NiO were observed at 2θ values of 37.2°, 43.3°, 62.8°, and 75.4°, respectively, matching the standard card PDF#47–1049. No characteristic peaks attributable to CuO or Al2O3 crystal phases were detected, indicating that CuO and Al2O3 exist in the catalyst in an amorphous or highly dispersed form. Additionally, it was observed that as the amount of Cu introduced increased, the peak shape of the NiO characteristic peaks gradually broadened, and the peak intensity gradually decreased, suggesting an interaction between the introduced Cu species and the Ni species. Using Scherrer's formula and the (200) plane of NiO as a reference, the crystallite sizes of NiO were calculated to be 4.8, 4.4, and 4.1 nm, respectively. This indicates that the NiO crystallite sizes in each catalyst are relatively small and highly dispersed, which can be attributed to the uniform complexation of cations on the layers of the layered double hydroxide (LDHs) precursor at the atomic level and the lattice confinement effect. The XRD patterns of the catalysts are presented in Fig. 3 (C). As shown in the figure, the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst exhibits characteristic diffraction peaks attributed to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of Ni, corresponding to the standard card PDF#04–0850, and also shows characteristic diffraction peaks attributed to the (111) and (220) planes of NiO (PDF#47–1049) at 2θ values of 37.2° and 62.8°, respectively. With the introduction of Cu and the increase in its content, the XRD diffraction peaks of Ni gradually shift to lower angles, the peak intensities gradually decrease, and the peak shapes become broader. The 2θ values were precisely determined using the (200) plane as a reference, and the interplanar spacings, lattice constants, and average crystallite sizes were calculated. The results are summarized in Table 1 . From the data in Table 1, it can be observed that with the introduction of Cu and the increase in its content, the interplanar spacing of the (200) plane gradually increases, the lattice constants also gradually increase, confirming the formation of a NiCu alloy phase[27,28], and the crystallite sizes gradually decrease, with average crystallite sizes of 6.2 nm, 5.7 nm, 5.4 nm, and 5.2 nm, respectively. These results indicate that NiCux/Al2O3 bimetallic catalysts with high dispersion and a homogeneous alloy phase have been successfully prepared using layered double hydroxide (LDHs) as the precursor. The H2-TPR profiles of the calcined samples are presented in Fig. 3 (D). The NiAl-LDO sample exhibits a broad hydrogen consumption peak in the temperature range of 350 °C to 800 °C, comprising two distinct characteristic reduction peaks at 550 °C and 680 °C, respectively. These peaks are attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed NiO species and NiO species with strong interactions with the support[29,30]. With the introduction of Cu species into the catalyst and the increase in Cu content, a new reduction peak appears at approximately 200 °C, characterized by a relatively sharp peak shape, which can be attributed to the reduction of CuO species[31,32]. Upon the introduction of Cu, the reduction peaks associated with highly dispersed NiO species and NiO species with strong interactions with the support shift to lower temperatures. Additionally, the peak area of the highly dispersed NiO species gradually increases, while that of the NiO species with strong interactions with the support gradually decreases[33]. The hydrogen consumption of each sample was quantitatively calculated based on the H2-TPR results, and the results are summarized in Table 2 . From the data in Table 2, it can be observed that as the Cu content in the catalyst gradually increases, the reduction peaks of the highly dispersed NiO species and the NiO species with strong interactions with the support decrease from 550 °C and 680 °C to 487 °C and 640 °C, respectively. Simultaneously, the hydrogen consumption changes from 64.1 mmol/g and 17.4 mmol/g to 78.1 mmol/g and 3.5 mmol/g, respectively. These data clearly demonstrate that there is a strong interaction between the introduced Cu species and the Ni species. Furthermore, the hydrogen spillover effect between metals facilitates the reduction of Ni species with strong interactions with the support, which is consistent with the conclusions drawn from the XRD analysis. To further understand the textural characteristics of the catalysts, the pore structure was characterized using low-temperature N2-physical adsorption, as shown in Fig. S8 . According to the latest IUPAC classification, all catalysts exhibit a type IV adsorption isotherm and an H2(b) type hysteresis loop, indicating the presence of an ordered mesoporous structure with relatively uniform pore channels. Additionally, the specific surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter data, obtained using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, are summarized in Table 3 . The results demonstrate that the pore structures of the catalysts are essentially consistent. The SEM images of the NiAl-LDH and NiCu0.4Al-LDH precursors, as well as those of the reduced catalysts, are presented in Fig. S9 (A–D). It can be clearly observed that the morphology of the LDHs is a nanoflower-like structure formed by the stacking of smooth two-dimensional nanosheets. The introduction of Cu does not affect the structure and morphology of the LDHs. After calcination and reduction, the catalysts still retain the two-dimensional nanosheet flower-like structure, but the surface exhibits a certain degree of wrinkling and is decorated with numerous spherical particles. This phenomenon may be attributed to the thermal decomposition of OH and CO3 2- on the surface of the LDHs layers during the calcination and reduction heat treatment processes, as well as the reduction of composite metal oxides to metallic Ni or NiCu alloy nanoparticles. The TEM and HRTEM images of the Ni/Al2O3 and NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalysts are presented in Fig. 4 . As shown in Fig. 4 (A), it is evident that the nanoparticles are uniformly dispersed on the two-dimensional nanosheet matrix. The particle size distribution, obtained using counting software, with an average size of approximately 8.42 ± 0.03 nm. Fig. 4 (B) shows the HRTEM image of Ni/Al2O3, revealing lattice fringes corresponding to the Ni(111) and NiO(111) crystal planes. Additionally, the HAADF-STEM analysis, as shown in Fig. 4 (C), indicates that the elements Ni, Al, and O are uniformly distributed within the catalyst. Similarly, as shown in Fig. 4 (D), the TEM image of the NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst clearly demonstrates that the nanoparticles are uniformly dispersed on the two-dimensional nanosheet matrix. The average particle size is approximately 8.12 ± 0.04 nm. Unlike the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, the HRTEM analysis in Fig. 4 (E) reveals interplanar spacings of 0.206 nm and 0.178 nm, which can be attributed to the NiCu(111) and NiCu(200) crystal planes, respectively. This is consistent with the XRD results and further confirms the formation of the NiCu alloy phase. The HAADF-STEM analysis of the NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst, as shown in Fig. 4 (F), indicates that the elements Ni, Cu, Al, and O are uniformly distributed within the catalyst. This fully substantiates the formation of a homogeneous NiCu alloy in the NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst prepared using LDHs as the precursor, with the NiCu alloy existing in a highly dispersed form within the catalyst. XPS was employed to characterize the elemental composition and valence state distribution on the catalyst surface, with the aim of elucidating the impact of Cu introduction on the surface electronic properties of the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, as shown in Fig. 5 . Fig. 5 (A) presents the full-spectrum XPS scan of the reduced catalyst, confirming the presence of Ni, Cu, Al, and O elements on the catalyst surface. Fig. 5 (B) displays the high-resolution XPS spectra of the Ni 2p3/2 region[34]. The signal peaks at binding energies of approximately 852 eV and 855 eV are attributed to Ni0 and Ni2+, respectively, while the signal peak at approximately 861 eV is assigned to the satellite peak of Ni2+. Fig. 5 (C) shows the high-resolution XPS spectra of the Cu 2p3/2 region[33]. The signal peaks at binding energies of approximately 932 eV and 933 eV are attributed to Cu0/+ and Cu2+, respectively, and the weak signal peaks at 940∼945 eV are attributed to the satellite peak of Cu2+. The relative content percentages of each species were determined by normalizing the peak areas and are listed in Table S2 . The data in the table indicate that the introduction of Cu leads to a gradual increase in the signal peak area attributed to Ni0. This is due to the fact that the presence of Cu species facilitates the reduction of Ni species. Consequently, under the same reduction conditions, a higher amount of Ni0 is generated on the catalyst surface, and the relative content of Ni2+ on the catalyst surface gradually decreases. These findings are consistent with H2-TPR and XRD results, further confirming that the introduction of Cu weakens the interaction between Ni species and the support, thereby altering the reduction behavior of Ni species. Additionally, compared to the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, the introduction of Cu results in a gradual shift of the binding energy of Ni0 in the bimetallic NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst towards lower binding energy, while the binding energy of Cu0 shifts towards higher binding energy. This suggests that electrons are transferred from Cu to Ni, indicating a significant electronic interaction between the two metals. Fig. S10 presents the XPS valence band spectra of the Ni/Al2O3 and NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalysts, showing valence band top positions at −0.07 eV and −0.57 eV, respectively. Clearly, as Cu is introduced, the valence band top of the catalyst gradually moves away from the Fermi energy level. Given that the electronic state of the d-band center is influenced by the valence charge near the Fermi energy level, the movement of the valence band reflects the displacement of the d-band center[35–38]. These results suggest that the introduction of Cu forms a homogeneous NiCu alloy, and the electronic interaction between Ni and Cu leads to the transfer of electrons from the 3d orbitals of Cu to the 3d empty orbitals of Ni, effectively modulating the d-band center of the active metal Ni. The H2-TPD profiles of each catalyst are presented in Fig. 6 . All catalysts exhibit asymmetric H2 desorption peaks within the temperature range of 50∼300 °C. Through peak fitting, four characteristic desorption peaks can be identified and designated as Hα, Hβ, Hγ, and Hδ. For the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, the peak maximum temperatures of the desorption peaks are 90 °C, 120 °C, 170 °C, and 220 °C, respectively. With the introduction of Cu, the peak maximum temperature of the Hα peak shifts to a lower temperature of 80 °C, while the other desorption peak temperatures remain relatively unchanged. However, quantitative analysis of the hydrogen desorption amounts (as listed in Table S3 reveals that, compared to the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, the total hydrogen desorption amount of the catalyst increases with the addition of Cu species. Specifically, the hydrogen desorption amount corresponding to the Hα peak of the NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst increases significantly from 28.9 μmol/g to 45.9 μmol/g, while the hydrogen desorption amounts corresponding to the Hβ and Hγ peaks decrease. This result suggests that the introduction of Cu can enhance the number of H2 adsorption activation sites. Furthermore, it indicates that the introduction of Cu species can promote the rapid desorption of H2 from the catalyst surface and effectively reduce the energy barrier required for H2 adsorption and dissociation. This effect may be attributed to the formation of a NiCu alloy phase upon the introduction of Cu, which regulates the d-band center of Ni and facilitates the desorption of H* from the catalyst surface. This conclusion aligns with previously reported research findings [12,39,40], and subsequent DFT calculations also confirm this. 3.3 Post-reaction catalyst characterization The excellent stability of the catalyst was confirmed experimentally and further demonstrated here by characterizations. The XRD patterns of the fresh and the post-reaction NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst are shown in Fig. S11 . It can be seen that the two catalysts have the same peaks, and the corresponding crystallite sizes are 5.2 nm and 5.6 nm, respectively, which confirms that there is no phase transition during the reaction process. In addition, combined with the HRTEM images ( Fig. S12 ), and the average nanoparticle sizes of the NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalysts are 8.12 ± 0.02 nm and 8.25 ± 0.03 nm before and after reaction, respectively, which proved the excellent structural stability of the catalysts. Meanwhile, the XPS spectra of the post-reaction catalysts ( Fig. S13 ) showed that the Ni 2p3/2 peaks and the Cu 2p3/2 peaks remained the same after reaction. These results indicate that the electronic structure of the NiCu alloy remains stable during the reaction. 3.4 Catalytic reaction mechanism Based on the aforementioned characterizations and discussions, further investigation was conducted using DFT theory to elucidate the fundamental mechanisms underlying the influence of Cu introduction on the catalyst's activity and selectivity. In line with the XRD and HRTEM characterizations, the Ni(1 1 1) and NiCu(1 1 1) surfaces were selected as the theoretical models of the catalyst[41]. Initially, the adsorption configurations and changes in adsorption energy of H atom, H2 molecule, MA molecule (Maleic anhydride, C4H2O3), and SAH molecule (Succinic anhydride, C4H4O3) on these two surfaces were systematically studied. The Ni(1 1 1) surface was used to simulate the surface of the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, while the NiCu(1 1 1) surface was used to simulate the surface of the NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst. The simulation results, as shown in Fig. 7 (A–H), present the optimal adsorption configurations and corresponding adsorption energy values for H atom, H2 molecule, MA molecule (Maleic anhydride, C4H2O3), and SAH molecule (Succinic anhydride, C4H4O3) on both the Ni(1 1 1) and NiCu(1 1 1) surfaces. Upon comparison, it is evident that the adsorption of each species on the NiCu(1 1 1) surface is significantly weaker than on the Ni(1 1 1) surface. The optimal adsorption sites for H atom on both surfaces after optimization are the hollow sites. However, the two surfaces exhibit distinct adsorption behaviors for H2 molecule. As shown in Fig. 7 C–D, the most stable adsorption configuration and adsorption energy of H2 molecule on the Ni(1 1 1) surface are presented, revealing that the optimized best adsorption site is the top site of Ni. Through simulations on the NiCu(1 1 1) surface, it was discovered that H2 molecule spontaneously dissociate after optimization to form two stably adsorbed H atoms. Subsequently, a detailed analysis of the dissociation behavior of H2 molecule on the Ni(1 1 1) and Cu(1 1 1) surface was conducted. The reaction pathway is illustrated in Fig. S14 . The calculation results indicate that a specific reaction energy barrier must be overcome for the dissociation of H2 molecule on the Ni(1 1 1) and Cu(1 1 1) surface. Overall, the introduction of Cu modulates the adsorption and dissociation behavior of H2 molecule, making the dissociation and migration of H2 molecule more favorable on the NiCu(1 1 1) surface, which is consistent with the H2-TPD characterization results. Fig. 7 E illustrates the optimal adsorption configuration and corresponding adsorption energy of the reactant MA molecule (Maleic anhydride, C4H2O3) on the Ni(1 1 1) surface. The MA molecule adsorbs via the CC bond at the top site, with Ni-C distances of 2.04 Å and 2.07 Å. The CC bond length increases from 1.34 Å in the gas phase to 1.44 Å, indicating that the adsorption weakens the CC bond. The distances between the three O atoms and the Ni atoms are 2.00 Å, 2.14 Å, and 2.00 Å, respectively, suggesting that MA is adsorbed parallel to the surface. For the adsorption of MA (Maleic anhydride, C4H2O3) on the NiCu(1 1 1) surface, as shown in Fig. 7 F, the CC bond adsorbs at the top site, with Ni-C distances of 2.41 Å and 2.43 Å. The CC bond is also weakened upon adsorption, with the bond length increasing from 1.34 Å in the gas phase to 1.54 Å. The distances between the three O atoms and the surface Ni atoms are 3.04 Å, 3.02 Å, and 3.12 Å, respectively, indicating that MA is adsorbed in a tilted configuration. The adsorption energies of the reactant MA molecule (Maleic anhydride, C4H2O3) in its most stable configuration on the Ni(1 1 1) and NiCu(1 1 1) surfaces are −1.77 eV and −0.8 eV, respectively. For the SAH molecule (Succinic anhydride, C4H4O3), the CNi distances on the Ni(1 1 1) surface are 3.34 Å and 4.48 Å, and it interacts and forms bonds with the metallic Ni through the oxygen atoms on the five-membered ring. On the NiCu(1 1 1) surface, the SAH molecule interacts and forms bonds with the metallic Cu through the oxygen atoms on the five-membered ring, similar to the adsorption mode on the Ni(1 1 1) surface. The adsorption energies of SAH (Succinic anhydride, C4H4O3) in its most stable configuration on the Ni(1 1 1) and NiCu(1 1 1) surfaces are −0.41 eV and −0.21 eV, respectively, as shown in Fig. 7 (G–H). The adsorption of reactant molecules on the catalyst surface is the initial step of the reaction. Subsequently, we performed detailed DFT transition state theory calculations to elucidate the specific hydrogenation process. In conjunction with the results from the experimental section and the consensus in the literature, it is widely accepted that in the hydrogenation of maleic anhydride, the hydrogenation of the CC bond occurs first, converting the molecule into SAH, followed by the hydrogenolysis of the CO bond in SAH to form GBL and THF. Given the most stable adsorption configurations of maleic anhydride on the Ni(1 1 1) and NiCu(1 1 1) surfaces, the probability of active H atoms attacking the C atoms at both ends of the CC double bond is similar. Therefore, the specific sequence of hydrogenation is not discussed. The hydrogenation of MA (Maleic anhydride, C4H2O3) initially produces the intermediate MAH* (C4H3O3*), which then continues to hydrogenate to form SAH (Succinic anhydride, C4H4O3). The elementary steps R1 (C4H2O3* + H* → C4H3O3* + *) and R2 (C4H3O3* + H* → C4H4O3* + *) are listed in Table 4 . The specific reaction pathways on the Ni(1 1 1) and NiCu(1 1 1) surfaces were simulated using DFT calculations. The calculated results for adsorption configurations, transition state energy barriers, and reaction heats are presented in Fig. 8 . Fig. 8 (A) illustrates the co-adsorption of reactants H and MA on the Ni(1 1 1) surface. It is observed that H is adsorbed at the fcc site. In the transition state TS, the H atoms on the surface migrate to the tilted top site, with a CH bond formation distance of 1.47 Å. The reaction energy barrier for this elementary process is 0.82 eV, corresponding to a reaction heat of 0.38 eV. On the NiCu(1 1 1) surface, when the reactant H atoms and MA molecules are co-adsorbed, H is located at the hcp site and migrates towards C atom. In the Transition State (TS), the H atoms migrate to the top site, with a CH bond formation distance of 1.46 Å. The reaction energy barrier and reaction heat for the hydrogenation of MA to MAH* are 0.53 eV and 0.04 eV, respectively. Fig. 8 (B) shows the process of the continuous hydrogenation of the intermediate MAH* (C4H3O3*) to SAH on the Ni(1 1 1) surface. The reaction energy barrier for this process is 0.66 eV, corresponding to a reaction heat of 0.22 eV. On the NiCu(1 1 1) surface, the reaction energy barrier and reaction heat for the hydrogenation of MAH* to SAH are 0.6 eV and 0.04 eV, respectively. Based on these results, it can be concluded that the elementary reactions of continuous hydrogenation involved in the hydrogenation of MA to SAH on the NiCu(1 1 1) surface have lower energy barriers compared to those on the Ni(1 1 1) surface, and the reaction heat during the reaction is also relatively lower. Therefore, the NiCu(1 1 1) surface is more favorable for the formation of SAH. The conversion of MA is a continuous hydrogenation process. Once MA is transformed into SAH, SAH undergoes further hydrogenation to produce deep hydrogenation products such as GBL or THF. Based on the conclusions from the experimental section, the primary products obtained during the experiment were SAH and GBL. Therefore, this section focuses on the critical step of selective hydrogenation of SAH, involving the possible elementary steps listed in Table 4 (R3: R3-1, R3-2, R3-3), primarily considering the hydrogenation sequence of H atom attacking one end of the CO double bond. Specifically, R3-1 involves H atoms initially attacking the C atom of the CO bond, R3-2 involves H atoms initially attacking the O atom of the CO bond, and R3-3 represents the direct cleavage of the CO bond. The specific reaction paths on the Ni(1 1 1) and NiCu(1 1 1) surfaces were simulated using DFT calculations, and the results of adsorption configurations, transition state energy barriers, and reaction heats are presented in Fig. 8 (C) and Fig. S15 (A–B). Fig. 8 (C) compares the results of the reaction path R3-1 on the Ni(1 1 1) and NiCu(1 1 1) surfaces. On the Ni(111) surface, the CO double bond of the SAH molecule interacts with Ni atoms through the O atom, with an ONi bond length of 2.08 Å. In the transition state TS, the CO bond is weakened, and the CH bond formation distance is 1.57 Å, corresponding to a reaction energy barrier of 0.56 eV and a reaction heat of −0.28 eV. On the NiCu(1 1 1) surface, the CO double bond of the SAH molecule is adsorbed on the top position of the surface Ni atom with a single O atom, with an ONi bond length of 2.16 Å. In the transition state TS, the CO bond is weakened, and the CH bond formation distance is 1.58 Å, corresponding to a reaction energy barrier of 0.63 eV and a reaction heat of −0.15 eV. Additionally, the hydrogenation processes of the R3-2 and R3-3 paths on the two surfaces were simulated, and the results are shown in Fig. S15 (A–B). By comparing the reaction energy barriers and reaction heats (Table 4), it is found that the optimal reaction path is R3-1. Overall, the further hydrogenation activation of the CO bond on the Ni(1 1 1) surface is more favorable both kinetically (0.56 eV) and thermodynamically (−0.28 eV) compared to that on the NiCu(1 1 1) surface. To elucidate the discrepancies observed in the SAH hydrogenation process, we conducted additional calculations to determine the energy required for SAH molecule to desorb from the metal surface and transition into the gas phase. The results of these calculations are illustrated in Fig. S16 . Specifically, the energy required for SAH desorption from the Ni(1 1 1) and NiCu(1 1 1) surfaces is 0.41 eV and 0.2 eV, respectively. Furthermore, the energy barriers for subsequent reactions on the NiCu(1 1 1) surface (R3-1: 0.63 eV, R3-2: 1.63 eV, and R3-3: 1.10 eV) are significantly higher than the energy required for desorption (0.21 eV). Consequently, SAH molecules formed on the NiCu(1 1 1) surface exhibit a higher tendency to desorb. To illustrate the essential cause for the marked disparity in the hydrogenation processes on the two aforementioned surfaces, a detailed computational analysis was conducted to investigate the strong electronic interaction between Ni and Cu. The positions of the d-band center of Ni on both surfaces were analyzed using density of states (DOS) calculations, and the results are presented in Fig. 9 (A). The activity of the catalyst is typically highly correlated with the electronic state of the catalytic center. The d-band center value of Ni on the Ni(1 1 1) surface is −1.82 eV. Upon the introduction of Cu, the d-band center value of Ni in the NiCu (1 1 1) shifts to −3.42 eV. This shift indicates that the d-band center of Ni moves further away from the Fermi energy level (Ef), leading to an increased electron population in the anti-bonding orbitals, which weakens the bonding strength between the reactant molecule or intermediate and the metal surface, as shown in Fig. 9 (B). Through Bader charge calculations, we found that the charge on Ni atoms in the NiCu alloy surface is higher than that on the pure Ni(1 1 1) surface. The electronegativities of Ni and Cu are 1.91 and 1.90, respectively. Based on the distribution of atomic charges on the metal surface layer, it can be inferred that after alloying, some electrons are transferred from Cu atoms to Ni atoms [42,43]. The strong electronic interaction between Ni and Cu results in the downward shift of the d-band center of Ni, as shown in Fig. 9 (C), which provides a schematic representation of the d-band center displacement. Based on the comprehensive analysis presented above, the following conclusions can be drawn: The NiCu(1 1 1) surface achieves an optimal adsorption state for reactant molecules and intermediates. Additionally, it facilitates the rapid dissociation of H2 molecules into active H* species, thereby significantly enhancing the efficiency of the hydrogenation reaction. Theoretical calculations indicate that the introduction of Cu significantly reduces the hydrogenation energy barrier of the CC bond in the MA molecule. When MA is converted to SAH, it is more likely to desorb from the metal surface rather than undergo further deep hydrogenation. In contrast, on the Ni(1 1 1) surface, after the transformation of MA into SAH, SAH tends to continue deep hydrogenation and convert into γ-butyrolactone (GBL). The results of the theoretical calculations are consistent with our experimental findings, which show that under the same reaction conditions, the NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst exhibits a higher conversion rate of maleic anhydride compared to the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, but there are significant differences in product selectivity. The NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst demonstrates higher selectivity for SAH, while the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst shows higher selectivity for GBL. Integrating the experimental conclusions with the results of DFT theoretical calculations provides compelling evidence that the alloying of Ni and Cu is an effective strategy for regulating the selectivity of maleic anhydride hydrogenation products. This offers a novel perspective for understanding the hydrogenation reaction mechanism of maleic anhydride at the molecular and atomic levels in our future research. 4 Conclusion In this study, leveraging the characteristic of uniform cation distribution at the atomic level on the layers of LDHs, a high-loading, highly dispersed, and homogenized NiCu bimetallic catalyst was synthesized using the LDHs as precursor. The research demonstrated that the introduction of Cu significantly enhances the hydrogenation activity of Maleic Anhydride (MA) and effectively modulates the selectivity of the products, enabling the directed synthesis of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) or γ-butyrolactone (GBL). At a reaction temperature of 210 °C, both the bimetallic NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst and the monometallic Ni/Al2O3 catalyst achieved 100 % conversion of maleic anhydride. On the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, the primary product of MA hydrogenation was γ-butyrolactone (GBL) with a selectivity of 94.2 %, whereas on the bimetallic NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst, the primary product was Succinic Anhydride (SAH) with a selectivity of 90.5 %. A series of characterizations and DFT theoretical calculations revealed that the introduction of Cu led to the formation of a NiCu alloy phase. The d-band center of Ni shifted away from the Fermi level, and more electrons occupied the anti-bonding orbitals, significantly weakening the bonding strength between the reactants and intermediates and the metal surface, and adjusting the adsorption configuration. This significantly reduced the hydrogenation energy barrier of the CC bond. After the transformation of MA into SAH, it was more likely to desorb from the NiCu(1 1 1) surface rather than undergo further deep hydrogenation. In contrast, on the Ni(1 1 1) surface, when MA was converted to SAH, SAH tended to continue deep hydrogenation and form γ-butyrolactone (GBL). The theoretical calculation results were consistent with the experimental findings. Importantly, stability tests confirmed that the catalyst exhibited excellent stability, with no significant decrease in activity after five cycles. The catalyst design and the research approach described in this study provide significant guidance for the development of more efficient and selective hydrogenation catalysts for maleic anhydride in future studies. coredata.dc:description: The primary products of the direct hydrogenation of Maleic Anhydride (MA) are Succinic Anhydride (SAH) and γ-butyrolactone (GBL). Achieving selective synthesis of these products by regulating the composition, structure, and textural properties remains a focal point in the research field of maleic anhydride hydrogenation. Based on the characteristic of atomic level uniform distribution of cations of layered double hydroxides (LDHs), a highly loaded, highly dispersed and homogenized NiCu alloy bimetallic catalyst was synthesized using NiCuAl-LDHs as precursor. Compared with Ni/Al2O3 catalyst derived from NiAl-LDHs, the introduction of Cu can effectively improve the hydrogenation activity of C=C bonds while inhibiting the hydrogenolysis of C=O bonds. Under identical reaction conditions, the primary product of the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was γ-butyrolactone (GBL) with a yield of 94.2 %, whereas the primary product of the NiCu0.4/Al2O3 catalyst was Succinic Anhydride (SAH) with a yield of 90.5 %. The introduction of Cu resulted in the formation of a homogeneous NiCu alloy phase in the catalyst, which significantly influenced the adsorption configurations and adsorption energies of the reactants and intermediates. This effect can be attributed to the electronic interactions between Ni and Cu, which shift the d-band center of Ni away from the Fermi energy level, thereby facilitating the directed synthesis of Succinic Anhydride (SAH) and γ-butyrolactone (GBL). These findings were confirmed by various characterization techniques and DFT theoretical calculations. Future catalyst development in maleic anhydride hydrogenation will significantly benefit from the design approach and research ideas presented in this study.
